name: Otomanguean (> Eastern Otomanguean)
1_comment: in the dictionary a separate word

name: Otomanguean (> Western Otomanguean)
1_comment: there is also a borrowing todabia ‘todavía’ with different position properties

name: Uto-Aztecan
1_comment: "The basic sense of oc is to signify that the action/process continues to be the same, undergoing no change or variation over the period of time in question." (Launey 2011: 64)
1_tam_restrictions: a.o. can be used in nominal clauses
1_other_uses: during this time, while, more (in front of a number)

name: Athabaskan-Eyak-Tlingit (> Tlingit)
1_comment: there is also a similarly looking particle tsú 'also', 'as well', 'too' with different position properties

name: Athabaskan-Eyak-Tlingit (> Athabaskan)
1_comment: see a glossed example with t'ahdii in Smith et al. 2007

name: Mayan
1_comment: is not sensitive to interuptions but I don't like the example; works similarly to correlative constructions
1_morphosyntactic_type_detailed: adverb + clause final particle expressing textual deixis

name: Salishan
1_morphosyntactic_type_detailed: adverb often written as an enclitic

name: Eskimo-Aleut
1_comment: there is also a suffix -ma 'being sometime'

name: Cochimi-Yuman
1_comment: "indicates that the subject has for some time been engaged in the activity or state denoted by the main verb and continues to be thus engaged"
1_adjacent_meanings: as a lexical verb 'be unchanged, be the same'

name: Iroquoian
1_comment: no special description, in almost all examples means 'before'

name: Caddoan
1_comment: "an activity or state that begins at some point in the past and continues, interrupted or not, to the time-frame referenced by the verb." There are also proclitics ‘continuative durative subordinator', ‘continuative subordinator', 'past continuative', 'continuative'
1_tam_restrictions: activity or state, habitual and non-habitual
